Medical Complex Expanded
reproduction, Biomedical engineering, neurobiology and medicine.
The second expansion facilities
soon to be completed are southand east-wing additions to the
School of Hygiene and Public
Health worth $4.5 million. The
expansion was made possible
through a $3 million grant from
the U. S. Public Health Service,
the remainder coming from private contributions.
Continued Leadership
University President Milton
Eisenhower points out that "The
new addition will enable Johns
Hopkins to continue its historic
role of leadership in public
health education and research."

Besides laboratories and classrooms for the training of physicians, sanitary engineers and
nurses, the new additions will
provide space for a 750-seat auditorium for faculty and postdoctoral students. A glass-enclosed penthouse restaurant will
cap the south wing of the building.
Floor space of the School of
Hygiene and Public Health will
be increased by about 75 percent
to a total of 3,000,000 square feet.
Green Green
A mall will eventually cover
the onetime urban wasteland
where the Research Center complex stands. Also nearing completion on the complex grounds
is a Children's Rehabilitation Institute. The entire complex will
be connected to the Johns Hopkins Hospital by a tunnel under
Monument Street.

The Student Council has announced that, as of next year,
Hopkins students will be able
to get discounts from numerous
Baltimore merchants through the
city. The discount is the result
of months of work by Council
Representative Ken Borow, a
freshman.
The discount policy will be organized by VISA, a nationally
known organization which has
arranged discounts for numerous other college campuses. The
University of Maryland, and numerous schools in the Washington D.C. area have discount policies organized by VISA. The discounts range from 10 to 25%'
depending on the store.
Visa will shortly approach approximately 400 stores in Baltimore in order to arrange discount policies for Hopkins students. Among the stores which
are expected to offer discounts
are grocery stores, record, clothing, liquor and hardware stores,
restaurants and movie theaters.
In September, the Council will
sell discount cards and booklets
with discount tickets for 25c.
These cards will be good for one
year and the booklet discounts
are for Baltimore stores.
This Monday, the Council will
offer cards and booklets for the
Washington, D.C. area for interested students. The discounts in
Washington include Baltimore
Bullet games, dinner at II Caesar's Restaurant and various
Georgetown clothing stores.

GREENWAY PHARMACY

IN THE HEART OF GILMAN HALL

CHARLES & 34TH ST.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MARCH 10, 1967

Fraternities Cull
New Membership
Last Saturday marked the end
of the formal fraternity rush
period with a little over 54% of
this year's frosh receiving bids
from one of the fourteen fraternities at Hopkins. Last year
52% of the freshman class
pledged fraternities.
Jerry Schnydman, president
of the IFC, expressed his pleasure with the total number who
decided to pledge. He particularly pointed out that many who
did not pledge lost weekend will
eventually
join
fraternities
through open rush.
Sixty-two percent of the freshman class submitted bids. This
would indicate that approximately 8% of the class, or 36 persons desirous of joining a fraternity, were not selected.

Goodbye To All What?
Like a man riding a kangaroo we have hopped the
fence and beaten the bush for news, informed analysis,
danger and levity. In retrospect let us offer a last gasp
before putting the kangaroo in the garage and going out
like a sad old candle.
We have not learned humility despite the fact that
'during our tenure as editors we confronted a drastic
revision of the traditional "hands-off" policy of the Administration. We would not presume to comment as to
whether the revision, has been motivated by a clear end
of patience with student frailties or an inability to understand or sympathize with student perceptions.
Nevertheless the creation of a Director of Student
Affairs is a positive indication that the University has
finally come to realize that the welfare of the Undergraduate Student Body is essential to the general
progress of the University.
Yet if the administrators of what we might construe as a new regard for the undergraduate do not have
the courage and vision to make a radical break down
from the past attitudes then we are now cynical enough
to forwarn of its failure.
There must be an honest attempt to bypass traditional methods of Administration-Faculty-Student contact. It will necessitate the giving up of formality and
holy pinosh. Yet it would be fair trade for real contact
with students not necessarily willing to put such concerns on a semi-professional basis.
One does not stand to learn very much by conversing with student "leaders" at Hopkins. The Hopkins
leader serves by default and thus is often the least qualified as a conversant or a representative.
Rather, the Administration must find some Way
of appealing to the nameless, non-contributive mass of
Hopkins students.
The News-Letter has always regarded this a paramount goal. We derive no small measure of satisfaction
from the fact that we succeeded in both creating and
baiting reaction. In doing so we have raised many issues.
They are not in themselves important: At the NewsLetter, indeed, "the medium is the message."
It is in the context of a medium amount of concern
for the state of the University that we offer these last
remarks,

Et Tu MacNamara
By HENRY HOCHERMAN
The other day, while I was
walking quietly along Charles
Street, minding my own business, a soothsayer approached,
and without so much as an introduction, placed his hoary
hand on my right shoulder and
gently whispered "sooth, sooth."
Being accustomed to the odd
characters that inhabit Charles
Street on an afternoon I didn't
find this strange at all, but began to become a little apprehensive when he moved yet closer, and in a manner very mysterious looked me in the eye
and whispered once again "sooth,
sooth." I tried to pass but he
wouldn't let me, and by words
and gestures he motioned me to
sit with him on a nearby bench.
This, with great wonder and
some trepidation I proceeded
to do.
You may be wondering now
how I knew that he was indeed
a soothsayer, and not some sort
of low life imposter, a graduate
student perhaps, or a member
of the student council. For one
thing, he held a placard that
said SOOTHSAYER (International Brotherhood of Soothsayers, AFL-CIO), for another, he
was dressed in standard soothsayer garb, down to a pair of
rope sandals, but most convincing of all was the fact that he
was soothing, as soothsayers invariably must be.

Sitting down on the bench he
gazed at me with a jaundiced
eye and softly said, "Beware
the Ides of March." Now we
were getting down to business.
The Ides of March I'd heard of.
With this I could identify, As I
looked at him he repeated the
mysterious phrase, and I came to
realize that I recognized his face.
Beneath the gray beard and worn
sackcloth was none other than
General Hershey, Director of the
Selective Service. Confronting
him with this discovery he looked at me deeply and spoke in a
soft voice. He seemed to get
older right before my eyes, and
his tone was sad. He told me
he was not General Hershey but
his great-great-grandfather, many
many generations in the past. He
had been in charge of procuring
troops for the Spartans in the
Pelopenesian Police Action, and
he had known Thucidides. His
son had fallen at Thermopolae.
He looked at me and he spoke,
and he told me this story, which
I pass on here for what it may
be worth. He spoke in an archaic
fashion, being, as he was, archaic.
"We were in a time of grave
war and great strife, and danger
and the fear of danger was over
the land. The state needed
soldiers to protect the Peloponesus and they came to me and
commanded me to draw them
forth from among the people. I
took at first the youths who had
no skills and did not seek learn-

ing, knowing that those of skill
and learning were needed to
create and maintain a victorious
nation. But the masters of war,
whose work is the destruction
of life and not its maintenance
came to me and commanded me
to draw forth from among the
students who sought knowledge
the youngest and the strongest,
for it is they who had spoken
out against the bloodshed and it
is they who sought justice.
"I did as I was ordered by
the generals and the leaders of
men and I took the scholars and
sent them off to the war where
many were killed and more were
maimed, and those who had held
the will to learn, lost that will
and came to be bitter over the injustice in the world.
"And the war was won and
the armies returned, but there
was nothing to return to. There
were no physicians and no practitioners of the law. No one to
lead and worse, no one to follow. And so my nation died, but
not in battle, and now there
are only pillars of stone to mark
its ever having existed. So Beware the Ides of March."
He then stood up and took the
number 11 bus and was last seen
in front pf the Civic Center
carrying a sign proclaiming the
coming of the end of the world.
But his story stayed in my mind,
and I fear the coming of the Ides
of March.
.Et tu MacNamara.

found personal visions. In "A
Man and A Woman," a very attractive young widow cannot escape the fond memories of her
dead husband. A handsome
widower-race driver draws her
into an affair (His wife, whom
he forgot rather quickly, committed suicide when he had a
racing accident) which she cannot accept. He insists; she gives
in. He has led her back to the
good life.
If the film had been shorter.
If the scenes had been fewer.
If there had been no dialogue.
"A Man and A Woman" would
have been a good movie. As it
is: most of the time boring, often slipshod, always very pretty.
Twenty minutes of racing cars
(which can be seen any weekend on ABC's "Wide World of
Sports") running a track, and,
later, thirty minutes of racing
cars (which can be seen anywhere in Europe) running a road
race. Yes, there are some very
good scenes. The camera hovers
before the windshield as the enamoured race driver speedily returns from Monte Carlo (where
the road race ended), through a
heavy rainstorm, to his new lover. Here the dialogue enhances,
does not downgrade, the scene.
Lelouch used tinted black-andwhite film and the finest color
film. This was not enough, however, to distract the viewer from
a nervous dialogue, another tired
theme, a few misappropriated
scenes. Only the haunting color
of a film like "Juliet of the Spirits" is distracting enough to
make the viewer forgive the filmmaker for his symbol-making.

Captive Frosh
To the Editors:
Hopkins's has many sacred
cows, but there is one which has
elicited practically no debate
this year. For the benefit of future little Hoppies who will be
arriving on Homewood for intellectual and academic stimulation,
let us have some dialogue on the
University's rule that freshmen
be required to live in dormitories.
0! The bounteous number of
reasons which our enlightened
Administrators may well name!
They could ask, "Why should
Hopkins be different? ALL colleges have this policy." They'll
surely point out that the incoming freshman does not have the
responsibility to live off campus
and handle his first year in college. The Administration might
even have the gall to remark
upon the ideal of the "Hopkins
Community." (a very handy argument, to be used when necessary but ignored most of the
time). On an educational plane,
our dear deans tell us that in
dormitories, one learns to live
with his neighbor and show social maturity. In the venerable
tradition of high humor, they
may quote the pamphlet 'put out
by Hopkins' Alumni, "The High
School Student's Question and
Answer Guide to the Johns Hopkins University": It states, "The
objective of the house unit is to
develop unity of purpose and
identification with a group
smaller than the total dormitory
population." Whew!
Well, why should Hopkins
change its policy when other colleges do not? Mainly, because all
outmoded traditions have to go
sometimes and naturally, someone has to be the FIRST. The
tradition has to go for the same
reason that one doesn't find
freshmen wearing beanies anymore. It is ridiculous, it is dated,
It is illogical.
However, how can an 18 year
old freshman possibly have the
responsibility to handle the first
year in college and live off campus too, without sacrificing
marks to a life of debaudhery?
Easily. He can do it as well as an
18 year-old sophomore. Yet, of
course there will be those who
will not have the responsibility
be they 18 or 22, but this is no
reason for the majority to suffer.
Hopkins's literature continually
repeats the theme that the Hopkins man is a mature, welldisciplined creature who is at
Hopkins because of his maturity
and responsibility. Thus, if the
student doesn't have the maturity and responsibility necessary
to handle an off-campus life, he
doesn't belong here in the first
place. (I expect no challenges to
that last statement, because I'd
Late to see anyone accuse the

Hopkins' catalogs of doubletalk). In brief, it seems that
Hopkins wants its students to
accept their responsibilities and
uphold the University's good
name, but it is scared stiff of
letting students exercise a few

of those responsibilities.
Finally, we are told of the
value of dorm life: one learns to
live with others, one gets the feel
of the "community," one identifies. This is garbage and the Ad(Continued on Page 9)

NEWS-LETTER

REPUBLICAN BIAS
I

Building Our Bridges With The Consular Treaty

By KENNETH W. BOND
The new Senate of the 90th
Congress will soon encounter the
first test of its potency over ratification of the controversial consular treaty.
First negotiated during the
Eisenhower Administration, the
treaty was signed by President
Johnson in 1964. In 1965-66 the
89th Congress shelved it in Sen.
Fulbright's (D., Ark.) Foreign Relations Committee where, until
a little over a month ago, it received neither hearings nor introduction on the Senate floor.
When hearings finally began
last January 23, it appeared as
though the consular treaty would
soon die, once and for all. FBI
Director J. Edgar Hoover reiterated that giving diplomatic
immunity to the 1,018 Soviet officials in the United States would

allow Soviet intelligence agents
to masquerade as consular employees, thereby making the
FBI's job much more difficult.
And right-wing lobbying organizations encouraged their audience to write Congressmen in
protest of the treaty.
Originally Apprehensive
To be sure, such pressure has
made a number of the 36 Republican senators a bit dubious and
apprehensive about voting to
ratify the treaty. Sen. Karl
Mundt (R., S.D.), ranking Republican on the Foreign Relations
Committee, largely
parroted
Hoover's feelings. Senate Minority Leader Dirksen opposed the
"diplomatic immunity" clause.
But something seems to have
made the conservative-moderate
Republicans come over in favor
of ratification. Last week Sen.

Dirksen (R, Ill.) announced his
suport of the treaty, aligning
with such vigorous GOP proponents as Sen. Mark Hatfield (R,
Ore.) and Sen. Thruston Morton (R., Ky.) who (to the surprise of many) has long praised
the treaty as a "safe and sound
approach toward better relations
with the Soviet Union." With
support mounting, Senate Majority Leader Mansfield (D., Mont.)
said that he will call the consular treaty to a vote this week.
Changed Attitude
The question now is why the
changed attitude in the Senate
Republican leadership? Perhaps
the petition from 15 House Republicans on February 10 urging
their partisans in the Senate to
ratify the treaty did the trick. Or
perhaps Sen. Margaret Chase
Smith's (R., Me.) affirmation

from Dean Rusk that the security problem of additional consulates is "both small and controllable" cooled down antiCommunist tempers. However,
it might be that after Sen. Dirksen and his followers took a long
look at the positive and constructive features of the treaty, they
abandoned the GOP practice of
bucking the Democratic majority for the sake of offering an
opposite alternative, swallowed
their pride in the fight against
"me-tooism," and sided with
those (both Republicans and
Democrats) who respond most
rapidly to the society's changing
needs and sentimentsOpponents to the consular
treaty have so far sounded highly emotional and irrational. On
the other hand, though, there
are many arguments supporting

the treaty, two in particular are
of immediate importance to
American citizens. First, if consulates are established, should a
U.S. citizen be arrested in Russia (or vice versa), the U.S. consulate woud be guaranteed notification of the arrest by Soviet
officials within three days, and
would have access to the person
within four days of the arrest.
Since 18,000 Americans visit
Russia each yeaT (as opposed to
900 Russians who annually sojourn to the U.S.), it goes without saying that the treaty largely favors U.S. interests.
Another Bridge
Second, the treaty would mark
the building of another "bridge
to the East." These "bridges"
(such as the Air-Accord treaty
signed last November which
would provide direct New York
to Moscow jet service, and the
Commerce Department's removal
of tariffs on "400 non-strategic
exports" to the Soviet Union and
East European satellites) are vital in securing peace with the
Soviets without another massive
arms build-up.
The Senate Republican leadership in realizing the significance
of the consular treaty will be intelligent and rational by endorsing ratification of it. And when
1968 rolls around, should anyone ask questions about "metooism" over the consular treaty,
the Republican senators need
only reply: "We just finished
what Ike and Dick started ten
years ago."

Grapplers Gain 3rd in -D;
HuntKeepsIndividual Title

sr

The Varsity wrestling team
finished third in a field of ten
teams
in
Mason-Dixon
the
Championships held last weekend at Old Dominion College in
Norfolk, Virginia.
Sporting a 3-7 dual meet record, the grapplers bypassed, in
the standings, several of the
teams which had defeated them
during the regular season. Baltimore University placed first and
Old Dominion College took second in the tournament.
Undefeated Champion
Bill Hunt easily retained the
heavyweight crown which he first
won as a sophomore last year.
Hunt was undefeated in thirteen
straight matches including tournament bouts this year.
Bill Swartz, last year's 167
Pound Mason-Dixon champion,
met defeat at the hands of last
Year's 177 pound champion, Miller of Hampton-Sidney in the
finals, forcing him to take second place at 167 lb.
Dryden—Skill and Guts
Rich Dryden who had been injured during a large part of
February, defeated his first two
oPponents. In the finals, Dryden
suffered a recurrence of his rib
injury and lost 9-6 to Goldberg
of American University.
Monte Ikemire placed fourth
in the 152 division when he lost
to Hvidding of Western Maryland in the consolation finals.
Bad Luck Takes Charge
Joe Griggs, last year's third
Place finisher at 137 pounds, had
the misfortune of wrestling
Dennis Knotts of Towson, the
first seed and last year's winner
in that class. Griggs lost in a
very tight bout.
Bad luck fell on Hopkins' 145
Pounder Harry Gotwals, as well.
Gotwals came up against the
number one seed in his first
round and lost.
Tom Copeland, giving up almost ten pounds, wrestled in
the 160 pound class. Copeland
lost his first match to Flynn of
Old Dominion who came in second, and his second match to
Rick Smertzler of Western Maryland who came in third.
Dennis Estis, replacing the injured John Gale in the 177
Pound class, won his first match
over Shrieves of Western Maryland. In his second match, Estis
lost to the number one seed

WHO'S GOT THE BUTTON?
I'm sure it has not escaped your notice that underlying
the adorable whimsy which has made this column such a
popular favorite among my wife and my little dog Spot,
there is a serious attempt to stay abreast of the problems
that beset the American college student.
Many a trip have I made to many a campus—talking to
undergraduates, listening to their troubles, hearing their
grievances, reading their buttons. (Incidentally, the second and third most popular buttons I saw on my last trip
were: "WALLACE BEERY LIVES" and "FLUORIDATE MUSCATEL." The first most popular button was,
as we all know,"SCRAP THE SCRAPE" which is worn,
as we all know, by Personna Super Stainless Steel Blade
users who, as we all know, are proud to proclaim to the
world that they have found a blade which gives them
luxury shave after luxury shave, which comes both in
double-edge style and Injector style, which does indeed
scrap the scrape, negate the nick, peel the pull, and oust
the ouch, which shaves so closely and quickly and truly
and beautifully that my heart leaps to tell of it. (If perhaps you think me too effusive about Personna, I ask you
to remember that to me Personna is more than just a
razor blade; it is also an employer.)
But I digress. I make frequent trips, as I say, to learn
what -is currently vexing the American undergraduate.
Last week, for example, while visiting a prominent Eastern university (Idaho State) I talked to a number of
engineering seniors who posed a serious question. Like
all students, they had come to college burning to fill themselves with culture, but, alas, because of all their science
requirements, they simply had had no time to take the
liberal arts courses their young souls lusted after. "Are
we doomed," they asked piteously, "to go through life
uncultured?"
I answered with a resounding "No!" I told them the
culture they had missed in college, they would pick up
after graduation. I explained that today's enlightened
corporations are setting up on-the-job liberal arts programs for the newly employed engineering graduate—
courses designed to fill his culture gap—for the truly enlightened corporation realizes that the truly cultured employee is the truly valuable employee.
To illustrate, I cited the well-known case of Champert
Sigafoos of Purdue.

When Champert, having completed his degree in wing
nuts and flanges, reported to the enlightened corporation
where he had accepted employment, he was not rushed
forthwith to a drawing board. He was first installed in
the enlightened corporation's training campus. Here he
was given a beanie, a room-mate, and a copy of the company rouser, and the enlightened corporation proceeded
to fill the gap in his culture.
First he was taught to read, then to print capital letters, then capital and small letters. (There was also an
attempt to teach him script, but it was ultimately
abandoned.)
From these fundamentals, Champert progressed slowly
but steadily through the more complex disciplines. He
was diligent, and the corporation was patient, and in the
end they were well rewarded, for when Champert finished, he could play a clavier, parse a sentence, and name
all the Electors of Bavaria.
Poised and cultured, Champert was promptly placed in
an important executive position. I am pleased to report
that he served with immense distinction—not, however,
for long because three days later he reached retirement
age.
Today, still spry, he lives in St. Petersburg, Florida,
where he supplements his pension by parsing sentences
for tourists.

The second expansion facilities
soon to be completed are southand east-wing additions to the
School of Hygiene and Public
Health worth $4.5 million. The
expansion was made possible
through a $3 million grant from
the U. S. Public Health Service,
the remainder coming from private contributions.
Continued Leadership
University President Milton
Eisenhower points out that "The
new addition will enable Johns
Hopkins to continue its historic
role of leadership in public
health education and research."

Besides laboratories and classrooms for the training of physicians, sanitary engineers and
nurses, the new additions will
provide space for a 750-seat auditorium for faculty and postdoctoral students. A glass-enclosed penthouse restaurant will
cap the south wing of the building.
Floor space of the School of
Hygiene and Public Health will
be increased by about 75 percent
to a total of 3,000,000 square feet.
Green Green
A mall will eventually cover
the onetime urban wasteland
where the Research Center complex stands. Also nearing completion on the complex grounds
is a Children's Rehabilitation Institute. The entire complex will
be connected to the Johns Hopkins Hospital by a tunnel under
Monument Street.

The Student Council has announced that, as of next year,
Hopkins students will be able
to get discounts from numerous
Baltimore merchants through the
city. The discount is the result
of months of work by Council
Representative Ken Borow, a
freshman.
The discount policy will be organized by VISA, a nationally
known organization which has
arranged discounts for numerous other college campuses. The
University of Maryland, and numerous schools in the Washington D.C. area have discount policies organized by VISA. The discounts range from 10 to 25%'
depending on the store.
Visa will shortly approach approximately 400 stores in Baltimore in order to arrange discount policies for Hopkins students. Among the stores which
are expected to offer discounts
are grocery stores, record, clothing, liquor and hardware stores,
restaurants and movie theaters.
In September, the Council will
sell discount cards and booklets
with discount tickets for 25c.
These cards will be good for one
year and the booklet discounts
are for Baltimore stores.
This Monday, the Council will
offer cards and booklets for the
Washington, D.C. area for interested students. The discounts in
Washington include Baltimore
Bullet games, dinner at II Caesar's Restaurant and various
Georgetown clothing stores.

Fraternities Cull
New Membership
Last Saturday marked the end
of the formal fraternity rush
period with a little over 54% of
this year's frosh receiving bids
from one of the fourteen fraternities at Hopkins. Last year
52% of the freshman class
pledged fraternities.
Jerry Schnydman, president
of the IFC, expressed his pleasure with the total number who
decided to pledge. He particularly pointed out that many who
did not pledge lost weekend will
eventually
join
fraternities
through open rush.
Sixty-two percent of the freshman class submitted bids. This
would indicate that approximately 8% of the class, or 36 persons desirous of joining a fraternity, were not selected.

Goodbye To All What?
Like a man riding a kangaroo we have hopped the
fence and beaten the bush for news, informed analysis,
danger and levity. In retrospect let us offer a last gasp
before putting the kangaroo in the garage and going out
like a sad old candle.
We have not learned humility despite the fact that
'during our tenure as editors we confronted a drastic
revision of the traditional "hands-off" policy of the Administration. We would not presume to comment as to
whether the revision, has been motivated by a clear end
of patience with student frailties or an inability to understand or sympathize with student perceptions.
Nevertheless the creation of a Director of Student
Affairs is a positive indication that the University has
finally come to realize that the welfare of the Undergraduate Student Body is essential to the general
progress of the University.
Yet if the administrators of what we might construe as a new regard for the undergraduate do not have
the courage and vision to make a radical break down
from the past attitudes then we are now cynical enough
to forwarn of its failure.
There must be an honest attempt to bypass traditional methods of Administration-Faculty-Student contact. It will necessitate the giving up of formality and
holy pinosh. Yet it would be fair trade for real contact
with students not necessarily willing to put such concerns on a semi-professional basis.
One does not stand to learn very much by conversing with student "leaders" at Hopkins. The Hopkins
leader serves by default and thus is often the least qualified as a conversant or a representative.
Rather, the Administration must find some Way
of appealing to the nameless, non-contributive mass of
Hopkins students.
The News-Letter has always regarded this a paramount goal. We derive no small measure of satisfaction
from the fact that we succeeded in both creating and
baiting reaction. In doing so we have raised many issues.
They are not in themselves important: At the NewsLetter, indeed, "the medium is the message."
It is in the context of a medium amount of concern
for the state of the University that we offer these last
remarks,

Et Tu MacNamara
By HENRY HOCHERMAN
The other day, while I was
walking quietly along Charles
Street, minding my own business, a soothsayer approached,
and without so much as an introduction, placed his hoary
hand on my right shoulder and
gently whispered "sooth, sooth."
Being accustomed to the odd
characters that inhabit Charles
Street on an afternoon I didn't
find this strange at all, but began to become a little apprehensive when he moved yet closer, and in a manner very mysterious looked me in the eye
and whispered once again "sooth,
sooth." I tried to pass but he
wouldn't let me, and by words
and gestures he motioned me to
sit with him on a nearby bench.
This, with great wonder and
some trepidation I proceeded
to do.
You may be wondering now
how I knew that he was indeed
a soothsayer, and not some sort
of low life imposter, a graduate
student perhaps, or a member
of the student council. For one
thing, he held a placard that
said SOOTHSAYER (International Brotherhood of Soothsayers, AFL-CIO), for another, he
was dressed in standard soothsayer garb, down to a pair of
rope sandals, but most convincing of all was the fact that he
was soothing, as soothsayers invariably must be.

Sitting down on the bench he
gazed at me with a jaundiced
eye and softly said, "Beware
the Ides of March." Now we
were getting down to business.
The Ides of March I'd heard of.
With this I could identify, As I
looked at him he repeated the
mysterious phrase, and I came to
realize that I recognized his face.
Beneath the gray beard and worn
sackcloth was none other than
General Hershey, Director of the
Selective Service. Confronting
him with this discovery he looked at me deeply and spoke in a
soft voice. He seemed to get
older right before my eyes, and
his tone was sad. He told me
he was not General Hershey but
his great-great-grandfather, many
many generations in the past. He
had been in charge of procuring
troops for the Spartans in the
Pelopenesian Police Action, and
he had known Thucidides. His
son had fallen at Thermopolae.
He looked at me and he spoke,
and he told me this story, which
I pass on here for what it may
be worth. He spoke in an archaic
fashion, being, as he was, archaic.
"We were in a time of grave
war and great strife, and danger
and the fear of danger was over
the land. The state needed
soldiers to protect the Peloponesus and they came to me and
commanded me to draw them
forth from among the people. I
took at first the youths who had
no skills and did not seek learn-

ing, knowing that those of skill
and learning were needed to
create and maintain a victorious
nation. But the masters of war,
whose work is the destruction
of life and not its maintenance
came to me and commanded me
to draw forth from among the
students who sought knowledge
the youngest and the strongest,
for it is they who had spoken
out against the bloodshed and it
is they who sought justice.
"I did as I was ordered by
the generals and the leaders of
men and I took the scholars and
sent them off to the war where
many were killed and more were
maimed, and those who had held
the will to learn, lost that will
and came to be bitter over the injustice in the world.
"And the war was won and
the armies returned, but there
was nothing to return to. There
were no physicians and no practitioners of the law. No one to
lead and worse, no one to follow. And so my nation died, but
not in battle, and now there
are only pillars of stone to mark
its ever having existed. So Beware the Ides of March."
He then stood up and took the
number 11 bus and was last seen
in front pf the Civic Center
carrying a sign proclaiming the
coming of the end of the world.
But his story stayed in my mind,
and I fear the coming of the Ides
of March.
.Et tu MacNamara.

found personal visions. In "A
Man and A Woman," a very attractive young widow cannot escape the fond memories of her
dead husband. A handsome
widower-race driver draws her
into an affair (His wife, whom
he forgot rather quickly, committed suicide when he had a
racing accident) which she cannot accept. He insists; she gives
in. He has led her back to the
good life.
If the film had been shorter.
If the scenes had been fewer.
If there had been no dialogue.
"A Man and A Woman" would
have been a good movie. As it
is: most of the time boring, often slipshod, always very pretty.
Twenty minutes of racing cars
(which can be seen any weekend on ABC's "Wide World of
Sports") running a track, and,
later, thirty minutes of racing
cars (which can be seen anywhere in Europe) running a road
race. Yes, there are some very
good scenes. The camera hovers
before the windshield as the enamoured race driver speedily returns from Monte Carlo (where
the road race ended), through a
heavy rainstorm, to his new lover. Here the dialogue enhances,
does not downgrade, the scene.
Lelouch used tinted black-andwhite film and the finest color

a nervous dialogue, another tired
theme, a few misappropriated
scenes. Only the haunting color
of a film like "Juliet of the Spirits" is distracting enough to

Captive Frosh
To the Editors:
Hopkins's has many sacred
cows, but there is one which has
elicited practically no debate
this year. For the benefit of future little Hoppies who will be
arriving on Homewood for intellectual and academic stimulation,
let us have some dialogue on the
University's rule that freshmen
be required to live in dormitories.
0! The bounteous number of
reasons which our enlightened
Administrators may well name!
They could ask, "Why should
Hopkins be different? ALL colleges have this policy." They'll
surely point out that the incoming freshman does not have the
responsibility to live off campus
and handle his first year in college. The Administration might
even have the gall to remark
upon the ideal of the "Hopkins
Community." (a very handy argument, to be used when necessary but ignored most of the
time). On an educational plane,
our dear deans tell us that in
dormitories, one learns to live
with his neighbor and show social maturity. In the venerable
tradition of high humor, they
may quote the pamphlet 'put out
by Hopkins' Alumni, "The High
School Student's Question and
Answer Guide to the Johns Hopkins University": It states, "The
objective of the house unit is to
develop unity of purpose and
identification with a group
smaller than the total dormitory
population." Whew!
Well, why should Hopkins
change its policy when other colleges do not? Mainly, because all
outmoded traditions have to go
sometimes and naturally, someone has to be the FIRST. The
tradition has to go for the same
reason that one doesn't find
freshmen wearing beanies anymore. It is ridiculous, it is dated,
It is illogical.
However, how can an 18 year
old freshman possibly have the
responsibility to handle the first
year in college and live off campus too, without sacrificing
marks to a life of debaudhery?
Easily. He can do it as well as an
18 year-old sophomore. Yet, of
course there will be those who
will not have the responsibility
be they 18 or 22, but this is no
reason for the majority to suffer.
Hopkins's literature continually
repeats the theme that the Hopkins man is a mature, welldisciplined creature who is at
Hopkins because of his maturity
and responsibility. Thus, if the
student doesn't have the maturity and responsibility necessary
to handle an off-campus life, he
doesn't belong here in the first
place. (I expect no challenges to
that last statement, because I'd
Late to see anyone accuse the

Hopkins' catalogs of doubletalk). In brief, it seems that
Hopkins wants its students to
accept their responsibilities and
uphold the University's good
name, but it is scared stiff of
letting students exercise a few

of those responsibilities.
Finally, we are told of the
value of dorm life: one learns to
live with others, one gets the feel
of the "community," one identifies. This is garbage and the Ad(Continued on Page 9)

NEWS-LETTER

REPUBLICAN BIAS
I

Building Our Bridges With The Consular Treaty

By KENNETH W. BOND
The new Senate of the 90th
Congress will soon encounter the
first test of its potency over ratification of the controversial consular treaty.
First negotiated during the
Eisenhower Administration, the
treaty was signed by President
Johnson in 1964. In 1965-66 the
89th Congress shelved it in Sen.
Fulbright's (D., Ark.) Foreign Relations Committee where, until
a little over a month ago, it received neither hearings nor introduction on the Senate floor.
When hearings finally began
last January 23, it appeared as
though the consular treaty would
soon die, once and for all. FBI
Director J. Edgar Hoover reiterated that giving diplomatic
immunity to the 1,018 Soviet officials in the United States would

allow Soviet intelligence agents
to masquerade as consular employees, thereby making the
FBI's job much more difficult.
And right-wing lobbying organizations encouraged their audience to write Congressmen in
protest of the treaty.
Originally Apprehensive
To be sure, such pressure has
made a number of the 36 Republican senators a bit dubious and
apprehensive about voting to
ratify the treaty. Sen. Karl
Mundt (R., S.D.), ranking Republican on the Foreign Relations
Committee, largely
parroted
Hoover's feelings. Senate Minority Leader Dirksen opposed the
"diplomatic immunity" clause.
But something seems to have
made the conservative-moderate
Republicans come over in favor
of ratification. Last week Sen.

Dirksen (R, Ill.) announced his
suport of the treaty, aligning
with such vigorous GOP proponents as Sen. Mark Hatfield (R,
Ore.) and Sen. Thruston Morton (R., Ky.) who (to the surprise of many) has long praised
the treaty as a "safe and sound
approach toward better relations
with the Soviet Union." With
support mounting, Senate Majority Leader Mansfield (D., Mont.)
said that he will call the consular treaty to a vote this week.
Changed Attitude
The question now is why the
changed attitude in the Senate
Republican leadership? Perhaps
the petition from 15 House Republicans on February 10 urging
their partisans in the Senate to
ratify the treaty did the trick. Or
perhaps Sen. Margaret Chase
Smith's (R., Me.) affirmation

from Dean Rusk that the security problem of additional consulates is "both small and controllable" cooled down antiCommunist tempers. However,
it might be that after Sen. Dirksen and his followers took a long
look at the positive and constructive features of the treaty, they
abandoned the GOP practice of
bucking the Democratic majority for the sake of offering an
opposite alternative, swallowed
their pride in the fight against
"me-tooism," and sided with
those (both Republicans and
Democrats) who respond most
rapidly to the society's changing
needs and sentimentsOpponents to the consular
treaty have so far sounded highly emotional and irrational. On
the other hand, though, there
are many arguments supporting

the treaty, two in particular are
of immediate importance to
American citizens. First, if consulates are established, should a
U.S. citizen be arrested in Russia (or vice versa), the U.S. consulate woud be guaranteed notification of the arrest by Soviet
officials within three days, and
would have access to the person
within four days of the arrest.
Since 18,000 Americans visit
Russia each yeaT (as opposed to
900 Russians who annually sojourn to the U.S.), it goes without saying that the treaty largely favors U.S. interests.
Another Bridge
Second, the treaty would mark
the building of another "bridge
to the East." These "bridges"
(such as the Air-Accord treaty
signed last November which
would provide direct New York
to Moscow jet service, and the
Commerce Department's removal
of tariffs on "400 non-strategic
exports" to the Soviet Union and
East European satellites) are vital in securing peace with the
Soviets without another massive
arms build-up.
The Senate Republican leadership in realizing the significance
of the consular treaty will be intelligent and rational by endorsing ratification of it. And when
1968 rolls around, should anyone ask questions about "metooism" over the consular treaty,
the Republican senators need
only reply: "We just finished
what Ike and Dick started ten
years ago."

campus. And for rationale, they point an
accusing finger at business and say it lacks
"social commitment."
Social commitment? We wish they could
Visit our Kearny, N. J. plant, where we
make cable and apparatus for your Bell
telephone company. But we have time for
other thoughts, other talents.
Like the situation in nearby Newark.
With civic and business leaders, we began buzzing with ideas."Let's teac-h higher
skills to some of the un-employed and
under-employed. Say, machine shop practice. They could qualify for jobs that are
going begging and help themselves as
well."
We lent our tool-and-die shop, _evenings. We found volunteer instructors. A
community group screened applicants.

Club donated classroom facilities. Another
company sent more instructors.
Some 70 trainees'enrolled. Their incentive? Self-improvement. Results to date?
New people at better jobs. Happier.
And this is only one of dozens of socialminded projects at Western Electric plants
across the country, where our first job is
making communications equipment for the
Bell System.
So, you don't give up ideals when you
graduate. If anything, at a company like,
say, Western Electric, you add to them.
And it's not just a theory. It's practice.
Satisfying. Come on and find out. And
watch a feathered cliche fly out the window.

WHO'S GOT THE BUTTON?
I'm sure it has not escaped your notice that underlying
the adorable whimsy which has made this column such a
popular favorite among my wife and my little dog Spot,
there is a serious attempt to stay abreast of the problems
that beset the American college student.
Many a trip have I made to many a campus—talking to
undergraduates, listening to their troubles, hearing their
grievances, reading their buttons. (Incidentally, the second and third most popular buttons I saw on my last trip
were: "WALLACE BEERY LIVES" and "FLUORIDATE MUSCATEL." The first most popular button was,
as we all know,"SCRAP THE SCRAPE" which is worn,
as we all know, by Personna Super Stainless Steel Blade
users who, as we all know, are proud to proclaim to the
world that they have found a blade which gives them
luxury shave after luxury shave, which comes both in
double-edge style and Injector style, which does indeed
scrap the scrape, negate the nick, peel the pull, and oust
the ouch, which shaves so closely and quickly and truly
and beautifully that my heart leaps to tell of it. (If perhaps you think me too effusive about Personna, I ask you
to remember that to me Personna is more than just a
razor blade; it is also an employer.)
But I digress. I make frequent trips, as I say, to learn
what -is currently vexing the American undergraduate.
Last week, for example, while visiting a prominent Eastern university (Idaho State) I talked to a number of
engineering seniors who posed a serious question. Like
all students, they had come to college burning to fill themselves with culture, but, alas, because of all their science
requirements, they simply had had no time to take the
liberal arts courses their young souls lusted after. "Are
we doomed," they asked piteously, "to go through life
uncultured?"
I answered with a resounding "No!" I told them the
culture they had missed in college, they would pick up
after graduation. I explained that today's enlightened
corporations are setting up on-the-job liberal arts programs for the newly employed engineering graduate—
courses designed to fill his culture gap—for the truly enlightened corporation realizes that the truly cultured employee is the truly valuable employee.
To illustrate, I cited the well-known case of Champert
Sigafoos of Purdue.

When Champert, having completed his degree in wing
nuts and flanges, reported to the enlightened corporation
where he had accepted employment, he was not rushed
forthwith to a drawing board. He was first installed in
the enlightened corporation's training campus. Here he
was given a beanie, a room-mate, and a copy of the company rouser, and the enlightened corporation proceeded
to fill the gap in his culture.
First he was taught to read, then to print capital letters, then capital and small letters. (There was also an
attempt to teach him script, but it was ultimately
abandoned.)
From these fundamentals, Champert progressed slowly
but steadily through the more complex disciplines. He
was diligent, and the corporation was patient, and in the
end they were well rewarded, for when Champert finished, he could play a clavier, parse a sentence, and name
all the Electors of Bavaria.
Poised and cultured, Champert was promptly placed in
an important executive position. I am pleased to report
that he served with immense distinction—not, however,
for long because three days later he reached retirement
age.
Today, still spry, he lives in St. Petersburg, Florida,
where he supplements his pension by parsing sentences
for tourists.
